stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and polishes a “secret path crystal” mechanic: carrying a crystal reveals (visually) otherwise invisible bridge/path geometry via vertex-color-driven rendering/shader work. Mid-stream he detours into a long, candid discussion about Nintendo legal risk and why he refuses to “stay quiet,” then reveals a major behind-the-scenes refactor: he’s systematically removing remaining Nintendo-authored code, re-implementing functions from scratch, and measuring memory/performance gains. The stream ends with gameplay-flow adjustments to prevent trivial speedrun skips, a brief progress checkpoint (Overworld 1 content complete through part 5), and plans for overworld decoration plus a small beta test after Bowser-level bugfixing.
stream_context.significance_reason: He reports a substantial codebase refactor to reach “0% Nintendo code,” quantifies size/performance improvements, completes the secret-path feature enough to mark an overworld milestone (done through part 5 / “first overworld is all good”), and outlines imminent beta testing and polish plans.

findings.summary: The core mechanic implemented is a carried “crystal” that makes an otherwise invisible bridge/path become visible (and usable), with the reveal driven by vertex colors and a custom combiner/shader-like setup on N64-style rendering.

Kaze struggles to make the reveal effect look good: the path appears “as intended” but visually unconvincing, prompting experimentation with alpha clamping, edge lines, scrolling textures (tiles scroll), and different tiling/tessellation patterns (e.g., hexagon tessellation).

A key constraint remains: the secret-path geometry is tangible even when not visible, which Kaze frames as a technical limitation he’s willing to accept because it doesn’t meaningfully change gameplay (and may even look cool in speedruns).
findings.quote: They are tangible even when not visible. This is due to technical limitations mostly, but it's fine.

findings.summary: After testing, Kaze discovers the secret path can be bypassed without interacting with the intended reveal, and he changes layout/placement to force at least some interaction with the mechanic (allowing “knowledge” skips, but not total non-interaction).
findings.quote: If you skip the secret path by knowing where it is, fine. If you skip the secret path by not even interacting with it, I'm not fine with that.

findings.summary: He reveals a major refactor in progress: he is going file-by-file removing any remaining Nintendo code and re-implementing it from scratch, reporting roughly ~30% size reduction in functions found not written by him, saving memory (kilobytes) and improving maintainability/performance.
findings.quote: I was working on going through all the source code again, and removing every piece of Nintendo code.

findings.summary: He shares a performance checkpoint: Overworld/Area 1 previously around ~50.02 FPS; now showing ~50.3 FPS even with asserts and profiler overhead, implying the real runtime is higher.

Kaze argues against the “don’t post about fangames or Nintendo will destroy you” mentality, claiming there’s no practical benefit to staying quiet; he believes takedowns don’t correlate strongly with whether projects ship because most fangames don’t release for internal reasons anyway.

He states his strategy is to get to “0% Nintendo code,” and says a true C&D would force removing Mario and other Nintendo characters; he also frames a takedown as potentially beneficial because it would justify turning the project into an original IP that could be more profitable.
findings.quote: If Nintendo does take me down... that is probably the best thing that could happen to me.

findings.summary: Tooling friction affects productivity: Blender becomes extremely laggy; Fast64 can crash when opening certain levels if enabled; Fast64 preview/render is described as inaccurate, complicating iteration on the reveal effect.

He fixes/diagnoses crystal-object behavior issues: missing respawn and jitter, and tracks one bug to an implicitly-declared function that GCC failed to warn about even with warnings enabled. He also notes a current regression where leaving an area and returning causes crashes after refactors.
He mentions another refactor outcome: instant warps now work under a new system and are easier to set up than before.
findings.quote: I was working on making instant warps work with my new system. And they do work now, it's now a lot easier to do instant warps in RTYI.

findings.summary: Progress checkpoint: Kaze considers the current star/segment “done for now,” says this completes the first four parts and that the project is “done up until part 5,” concluding that “the first overworld is all good.” Next is population/polish (Yoshi villagers after Bowser 1, more wildlife) and bugfixing Bowser 1, after which he’ll ship a build to a single beta tester to test five levels.

Zeina and Kaze discuss audience reaction to a recent video segment featuring her (Lilaa/petting animation bit): they saw many positive comments but also a noticeable amount of transphobic comments; Kaze notes the positive outweighed the negative.

biobak.summary: Kaze anticipates Biobak may revise/adjust the secret path later, suggesting level pathing/layout is still collaborative and not fully locked.
biobak.quote: The path might still change with Biobak later, so I'm not too worried about it.

zeina.summary: Zeina confirms she noticed transphobic comments in response to her presence in a recent video, while also acknowledging many comments praised the humor/animation.
zeina.quote: Yes, I did get a lot of transphobic comments. You are correct.

findings.summary: Kaze says he and Sauraen discussed a new armature format that would save time. Kaze wants that format in place before he reduces Mario’s skeleton from 20 bones to 15, to avoid reworking the armature twice.
Kaze asks Lilaa whether there’s a newer Fast64 Render version that might resolve unusable lag/crashes, implying Lilaa has tooling knowledge or access to updated builds.

memorable_quotes.context: A concrete design principle: he’s okay with skill/knowledge-based sequence breaks, but not with layouts that make the intended mechanic irrelevant.

key_stories.title: Building the secret-path crystal reveal (and making it look good)
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a carried-crystal mechanic that reveals a hidden bridge/path via vertex-color-driven appearance. The technical goal is not just functionality but a reveal that reads clearly and feels “mysterious/ghostly,” without ugly edges or fake-looking transitions.
key_stories.challenge: How to render an appearing/disappearing path only when the crystal is held, without duplicating meshes or accidentally revealing unrelated platforms, and while achieving a convincing N64-style visual transition.
key_stories.process: He explores design alternatives (generic platforms vs a single collision path), then commits to a reveal shader approach using alpha/combiner tricks, tile scrolling, and texture pattern experiments (diamond/crystal-like patterns, hex tessellation). He iterates through incorrect/inverted fades, preview inaccuracies, and tangibility limitations.
key_stories.outcome: He gets a workable effect with glow added, acknowledges remaining issues (jitter, invisibility edge cases), and accepts that collisions remain tangible even when invisible due to constraints. He declares the ‘secret path’ largely done, with possible later tweaks.
key_stories.key_quote: They are tangible even when not visible. This is due to technical limitations mostly, but it's fine.

key_stories.title: Speedrun-proofing the secret path so the mechanic matters
key_stories.summary: During playtesting, Kaze realizes players can bypass the secret path without engaging with it, undermining the entire point of the crystal feature. He immediately adjusts placement to preserve intended interaction while still allowing knowledgeable skips.
key_stories.challenge: The level layout allowed reaching the destination without using or even touching the revealed path.
key_stories.process: He tests the route “blind,” notices the trivial bypass, and repositions the path/crystal setup so progression requires interacting with the revealed geometry (or at least triggering the system).
key_stories.outcome: He locks in a stricter interaction requirement: sequence breaking is acceptable, but total irrelevance of the mechanic is not.
key_stories.key_quote: If you skip the secret path by not even interacting with it, I'm not fine with that.

key_stories.title: The quiet refactor: removing Nintendo code and rebuilding systems
key_stories.summary: In the middle of a legal discussion, Kaze reveals he’s been silently refactoring the codebase to remove remaining Nintendo-authored code, re-implementing functions and taking the opportunity to optimize. This directly supports his stated goal of shipping with “0% Nintendo code.”
key_stories.challenge: Legal and technical risk of relying on Nintendo code, plus maintainability/performance issues from legacy implementations.
key_stories.process: He audits files, deletes non-self-authored functions, reimplements them, and measures improvements. He also benchmarks performance in Overworld/Area 1 and notes side effects (new crashes/regressions that need fixing).
key_stories.outcome: He reports ~30% function-size reductions on average for replaced code, small memory savings, modest FPS improvements, and a clearer path toward a legally safer release strategy.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm deleting every function I find, and I'm re-implementing this from scratch, basically.

key_stories.title: From milestone to beta: locking Overworld 1 and planning population polish
key_stories.summary: Kaze frames current progress as a structured milestone (“done up until part 5,” “first overworld is all good”) and shifts focus from mechanics to world ‘life’: adding villagers and ambient creatures after Bowser 1. He also outlines a near-term beta plan once remaining bugfixes are complete.
key_stories.challenge: Transition from feature-building to shippable content, including stability issues (Bowser level bugs, re-entry crashes) that block external testing.
key_stories.process: He finishes the star/secret-path section, lists upcoming decoration targets (Yoshi villagers, spiders, grasshoppers, butterflies, flower fields), and prioritizes bugfixing the Bowser level and overworld polish.
key_stories.outcome: He intends to ship a build to one beta tester to test five levels once Bowser-level bugs and critical overworld issues are resolved.

open_questions.topic: “0% Nintendo code” refactor scope and endgame
open_questions.context: Kaze says he’s removing every remaining Nintendo function and reimplementing it, measuring significant size reductions and small performance gains, and tying this to legal safety and release plans.
questions: What specific pieces of Nintendo code were still in the project when you started this pass—animation, movement, camera, object logic, audio?
How did you verify a function was “Nintendo code” versus decomp community edits or earlier hack-era modifications?
At what point will you consider the project “0% Nintendo code,” and what kind of audit or proof would satisfy you?
What broke during the refactor (like the area re-entry crash), and how do you manage regressions without slowing development to a halt?

open_questions.topic: Contingency plan if Nintendo issues a real C&D
open_questions.context: Kaze argues staying quiet is pointless, believes romhacks sit in a deliberate legal gray zone, and claims a takedown could be beneficial because it would justify pivoting to an original IP (and removing Mario/goombas).
questions: What would the first 30 days after a C&D look like—what gets removed first, and what stays?
How far have you already designed the world to stand on its own without Mario branding (characters, lore, iconography)?
What parts of RTYI feel most ‘Mario-dependent’ today, and what would be the hardest to replace quickly?
Would you continue public development transparently during a pivot, or would you change how you communicate/releases?

open_questions.topic: New armature format with Sauraen + reducing Mario’s skeleton from 20 bones to 15
open_questions.context: Kaze wants to avoid reworking Mario’s rig twice; he and Sauraen discussed a new armature format meant to save time and improve the pipeline.
questions: What is wrong or limiting about the current armature/animation conversion that came from Nintendo’s format?
What does the proposed new armature format actually change (data layout, tooling, export/import steps, runtime skinning)?
Why is 15 bones the target—performance, memory, animation quality, or tooling simplicity?
What would success look like for this pipeline change: faster iteration, fewer bugs, better compression, or more expressive animations?

open_questions.context: Kaze accepts that the hidden path can still be collided with while invisible due to technical limitations, but believes it won’t harm gameplay much.
questions: What exactly is the technical blocker to making collision conditional—engine architecture, collision BVH structure, or N64 object list constraints?
Did you consider design countermeasures (like ‘void’ volumes, knockback, or camera framing) to prevent players from using invisible collision unintentionally?
Would you ever revisit this if playtesters/speedrunners find it breaks the intended experience?
